text.p: Grocer Davids Ltd said on Tuesday it was confident of greater profits in the 1996/97 year and beyond as the full benefits of the QIW merger emerged.

"The past year has seen continued growth and development of the company on many fronts. I am confident of even greater growth and profits during fiscal 1997, continuing through fiscal 1998 as the full benefits of the QIW merger benefits emerge," executive chairman John David said in Davids' results for 1995/96.

Earlier Davids reported an 11.7 percent higher net profit of A$51.77 million in the year to June 30, 1996 and set a five cents per share final dividend, taking the total dividend to a steady 10 cents.

There were no abnormal items. Analysts had forecast net profit before abnormals to rise to about A$53.6 million. Davids said that since the acquisition of QIW and its subsidiary Composite Buyers Ltd, there had been a net reduction in the number of 751 employees. "Expected annual savings from this reduction alone is in excess of A$30 million. Further inventory savings are estimated to be A$60 million," it said.
Davids said the company had embarked on a surplus asset realisation programme.
"Real estate valued at A$50 million is currently on the market," it said.
Davids also said wholesale trading conditions were tough, but were showing signs of improvement.
Davids said its food service operations continued to grow ahead of grocery industry trends and its liquor market sales business continued to have outstanding growth.
Davids shares were up five cents at A$1.74 at 2.20 pm (0420 GMT). -- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 373-1800
